facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1357 to 1359 of 1972 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1357 to 1359 of 1972.

facts.text: Appeals by certificate from judgment and order dated January 10, 1972 of Delhi High Court in Civil Writ petitions Nos. 405, 381 and 486 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by certificate from the judgment and order dated January 10, 1972 of Delhi High Court at New Delhi in Civil Writ petitions Nos. 405, 381 and 486 of 1971.

facts.text: Delhi High Court dismissed the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the writ petitions and hence these appeals.

facts.text: Appellants are three public limited companies having factories in Haryana State manufacturing and selling sugar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are three public limited companypanies having factories in Haryana State where they carry on the business of manufacturing and selling sugar, an essential companymodity within the meaning of the Act.

facts.text: Central Government required sugar factories including appellants to sell 60% of their production during 1970-71 at fixed prices.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of power reserved to it under s. 3  2   f  and s. 3  3C , the Central Government required the sugar factories, including the appellant companypanies to sell to it 60 of their production during the year 1970-71 at prices fixed by it,

facts.text: Price fixed for factories in Haryana zone under Sugar Price Determination Order, 1971 is Rs. 124.63 per quintal.

anchor.surface_text: the price fixed for the factories in Haryana zone under the impugned order being Rs. 124.63 per quintal.

facts.text: Writ petitions filed in Delhi High Court to quash Sugar Price Determination Order, 1971 and for direction to refix ex-factory price for 1970-71 sugar.

anchor.surface_text: These three appeals, by certificate, arise out of three writ petitions filed in he High Court of Delhi for quashing the Sugar  Price Determination  Order, 1971 made under s. 3 3C  of the Essential Commodities Act, 10 of 1955,

facts.text: Sugar is an essential commodity within the meaning of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: an essential companymodity within the meaning of the Act.

facts.text: Central Government enacted Sugar Price Determination Order, 1971 under section 3(3C) of Essential Commodities Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: for quashing the Sugar  Price Determination  Order, 1971 made under s. 3 3C  of the Essential Commodities Act, 10 of 1955,

facts.text: Partial control policy announced in August 1967 requiring 60% levy sugar and 40% free sale.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, Government announced in August 1967 its policy of partial companytrol under which 60 of the output of sugar would be acquired and the balance of 40 would be left for free sale.

facts.text: Sub-section 3C inserted in section 3 of Essential Commodities Act by Act 36 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-sec. 3C, with which we are presently companycerned was in- serted in sec. 3 by sec. 3 of Act 36 of 1967.

facts.text: Tariff Commission in 1969 constructed cost schedules for 22 zones including Haryana with return of Rs. 10.50 per quintal.

anchor.surface_text: Government in 1968 requested the Tariff Commission to companystruct fresh companyt schedules. ... The Commission, therefore, suggested a uniform amount per quintal as a margin to be added to the other companyts in arriving at the fair price of sugar. The Commission for the reasons aforesaid was of the view that an amount of Rs. 10.50 would be a fair return

facts.text: Government accepted Tariff Commission recommendations except rehabilitation by resolution dated February 20, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The Government did number accept the recommendation as to rehabilitation and deferred its decision thereon for reasons stated in its resolution dated February 20, 1970,

facts.text: Government fixed ex-factory price at Rs. 124.63 per quintal on January 8, 1971 for 1970-71 Haryana sugar.

anchor.surface_text: the Government had fixed the price of Rs. 124.63 on January 8, 1971

facts.text: Delhi High Court by order dated September 14, 1971 directed Government to disclose basis of price fixation.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellants, the High Court, therefore, by its order dated September 14, 1971 called upon the Government to show the basis on which it had fixed the, price.

facts.text: Deputy Secretary Ministry of Agriculture filed additional affidavit dated September 14, 1971 stating price Rs. 126.93.

anchor.surface_text: The Government thereupon filed an additional affidavit of the Deputy Secretary to the Ministry of Agriculture dated September 14, 1971 according to which on the available data before it the price would companye to Rs. 126.93.

facts.text: Actual recovery for Haryana factories in 1970-71 was 8.69% and duration 162 days.

anchor.surface_text: The actual figures of the year for duration and recovery were number in dispute. They were 162 days and 8.69 respectively.

facts.text: Appellants claimed loss of Rs. 5.20 per quintal on levy sugar for 1970-71.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants case was that on the actuals worked out for the year 1970-71, the price would be Rs. 129.42, thus causing to them a loss of Rs. 5.20 per quintal on levy sugar.

facts.text: High Court added Rs. 3.22 to price making it Rs. 127.85 per quintal.

anchor.surface_text: Adding Rs. 3.28 to the Government price, the High Court worked out the fair price at Rs. 127.85 instead of Rs. 124.63.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals fail and are dismissed.

facts.text: Haryana purchase tax on cane increased from 24 paise to 50 paise per quintal effective April 1, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor General also companyceded that purchase tax on cane in Haryana was increased during the year 1970-71 from 24 paise to 50 paise per quintal with effect from April 1, 1970

facts.text: Total levy sugar for appellants 65,741 quintals in 1970-71.

anchor.surface_text: The loss on this calculation, according to them, would companye to Rs. 3 lacs and odd on levy sugar which totaled 65,741 quintals.

facts.text: Sugar decontrolled on May 25, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: from October 1970 to May 25, 1971 when sugar was totally decontrolled

facts.text: Tariff Commission 1969 ex-works price for Haryana Rs. 128.69 per quintal based on 8.70% recovery and 125 days duration.

anchor.surface_text: The ex-works price worked out in the Tariff Commission Re- Port, 1969 for Haryana zone for the next three years, i.e., 1969-70 to 1971-72, based on the average recovery and average duration of the past five years  1963-64 to 1967- 68 , i.e., 8.70 and 125 days, was Rs. 128.69 per quintal.

anchor.surface_text: three writ petitions filed in he High Court of Delhi for quashing the Sugar Price Determination Order, 1971

issues.text: what is the true interpretation of S. 3 3C

anchor.surface_text: The principal questions arise in these appeals 1 what is the true interpretation of S. 3 3C , and  2 whether the price of Rs. 124.63 was in accordance with the provisions of s. 3 3C ?

issues.text: whether the price of Rs. 124.63 was in accordance with the provisions of s. 3 3C

anchor.surface_text: The principal questions arise in these appeals 1 what is the true interpretation of S. 3 3C , and  2 whether the price of Rs. 124.63 was in accordance with the provisions of s. 3 3C ? Before we proceed to consider these questions it would, we think, be better to set out briefly the history

issues.text: whether the price fixed under the impugned order, i.e., Rs. 124.63, is in consonance with s. 3 3C

anchor.surface_text: the only question left for consideration is whether the price fixed under the impugned order, i.e., Rs. 124.63, is in consonance with s. 3 3C ? The ex-works price worked out in the Tariff Commission Re- port, 1969 for Haryana zone for the next three years, i.e., 1969-70 to 1971-72, based on the average recovery and average duration of the past five years  1963-64 to 1967- 68 , i.e., 8.70 and 125 days, was Rs. 128.69 per quintal.

issues.text: whether a reasonable return on the capital employed in the business of manufacturing sugar under S.3(3C)(d) must mean the business as a whole and not the business of manufacturing levy sugar only

anchor.surface_text: In, this conclusion we derive a two-fold support, firstly, from the language used in cl.  d  itself, viz., a reasonable return on the capital employed in the business of manufacturing sugar, which must mean the business as a whole and not the business of manufacturing levy sugar only, and secondly, from the fact of the Commission having all along used the, same phraseology while recommending Rs. 10.50 per quintal as an addition by way of a reasonable return on the capital employed in the industry.

issues.text: Have the Haryana factories then not received in fact during 1970-71 the reasonable return as envisaged by sub-s. 3C

arguments.claim: Sub-section 3C deals only with levy sugar, so reasonable return under cl. d is only on capital for levy sugar production

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants and for the several interveners, however, contended (1) that since sub-sec. 3C was enacted after the policy of partial control leaving a part of the stock for free market was decided upon, the sub-section must be held to deal with levy sugar only, and (2) that the language of the sub-section as also of its cls. a, b and c shows that it dealt with and was concerned with levy sugar only and that therefore cl. d must also be construed to be dealing with levy sugar.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r the impugned order, i.e., Rs. 124.63, is in companysonance with s. 3 3C ? The ex-works price worked out in the Tariff Commission Re- port, 1969 for

arguments.court_reasoning: Language refers to business of manufacturing sugar as whole; historical cost schedules for entire production; partial control assumes free market profit offsets levy

arguments.claim: Cl. d must mean return on whole capital leads to contradictory results: floor cane price for a but actual for d

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that besides the necessity of giving to cl. d the same meaning as one would have to give to cls. a, b and c, if cl. d were to be construed to mean return on the whole of the capital employed, there would ensue a contradictory and even an anomalous result. For purposes of cl. a, one would have to take the floor price of cane fixed by Government, but for cl. d, the actual price of cane paid by a unit would have to be taken into account

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 1967- 68 , i.e., 8.70 and 125 days, was Rs. 128.69 per quintal. That figure was made up of the following Wages and salaries Rs. 11.70  2  stores, fue

arguments.court_reasoning: Price determined for entire sugar having regard to min cane price etc.; consistent with zonal cost schedules using min cane price

arguments.claim: Interpreting cl. d as return on whole business negates partial control scheme by allowing govt to fix levy price below cost assuming free sugar profit

anchor.surface_text: Counsel also urged that if cl. d were construed to mean reasonable return on the production of the entire stock and not levy sugar only, it would mean negativing the entire scheme of partial control which was intended to leave a reasonable return on that part of the stock which was required thereunder to be sold irrespective of the return obtained by sale of the rest of his stock in a free market.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ing 1969-70 at prices ranging from Rs. 126.21 to Rs. 138.01, exclusive of excise duty, and from October 1970 to May 25, 1971 when sugar was totally de

arguments.court_reasoning: Partial control incentivizes efficiency via free market; fair price on zonal averages for industry as whole harmonizes interests

arguments.claim: Such construction defeats partial control object: manufacturers won't pay cane above min without assured levy return

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it would be contrary to that concept if the profits made in respect of free sugar were to be taken into account as a cushion if the fair price fixed for levy sugar was not equivalent to the actual cost of production and were to result in a return less than the reasonable return on that part of the stock, or even a deficit. Such a construction would, they argued, permit the Government to fix a price which would not leave such a return on the ground that sale of free sugar would bring in sufficient surplus to make up the deficit, if any, on the levy sugar.

arguments.court_reasoning: Assumption of partial control is higher cane via free profit; history shows zonal schedules for whole

arguments.court_reasoning: Impracticable; rewards inefficiency; fair price on representative cross-section

arguments.claim: Govt price Rs.124.63 causes loss of Rs.5.20/quintal on levy sugar based on actuals 1970-71

anchor.surface_text: As against the levy price worked out by Government at Rs. 126.93, the appellants case was that on the actuals worked out for the year 1970-71, the price would be Rs. 129.42, thus causing to them a loss of Rs. 5.20 per quintal on levy sugar.

arguments.court_reasoning: Actual realization on levy+free up to decontrol Rs.130.77 > cost Rs.130.13 incl additions; reasonable return achieved

arguments.claim: Additional costs: interest Rs.2.29, freightage 63p, deterioration, etc. raising cost to Rs.138.93

anchor.surface_text: To the figure of Rs. 129.42, the appellants add additional cost of interest, increase in freightage by road and rail during the year, deterioration in quality, thus bringing the cost to Rs. 138.93. The loss on this calculation, according to them, would come to Rs. 3 lacs and odd on levy sugar which totaled 65,741 quintals.

arguments.court_reasoning: Some additions allowable but interest/deterioration/freight not sustainable; overall return ok incl free sugar

arguments.claim: S.3(3C) price determination has regard to entire production cost schedules, return on whole business

anchor.surface_text: The fair price, therefore, has to be determined on the minimum price of cane fixed by Government, the manufacturing cost on the basis of zonal cost-schedules, the tax or duty applicable in the zones and must be so structured as to leave in the ultimate result to the industry a reasonable return on the capital employed by it in the business of manufacturing sugar.

arguments.claim: Historical practice: cost schedules by expert bodies for entire production, not levy only

anchor.surface_text: The history of control over sugar set out above shows that right from 1958 and even earlier, ex-factory prices of sugar were worked out on the basis of cost-schedules prepared by expert bodies appointed for that purpose, that such prices and cost schedules were prepared in respect of the entire production and not in relation only to that part of it which was required to be sold to Government

arguments.claim: Language of cl.d: 'business of manufacturing sugar' means whole, not levy only

anchor.surface_text: In this conclusion we derive a two-fold support, firstly, from the language used in cl. d itself, viz., a reasonable return on the capital employed in the business of manufacturing sugar, which must mean the business as a whole and not the business of manufacturing levy sugar only

arguments.claim: Tariff Commission used same phraseology for Rs.10.50 return on whole industry

anchor.surface_text: and secondly, from the fact of the Commission having all along used the same phraseology while recommending Rs. 10.50 per quintal as an addition by way of a reasonable return on the capital employed in the industry.

arguments.claim: Govt price Rs.124.63 accords with S.3(3C): based on Tariff Comm schedules minus rehab, adjustments

anchor.surface_text: the only question left for consideration is whether the price fixed under the impugned order, i.e., Rs. 124.63, is in consonance with s. 3 3C ? The ex-works price worked out in the Tariff Commission Report, 1969 for Haryana zone... was Rs. 128.69 per quintal... Deducting Rs. 2 from the ex-works price worked out by the Commission, the Commissions ex-works price would be Rs. 126.69

arguments.claim: Actuals show reasonable return achieved: realizations Rs.130.77 > costs Rs.130.13 incl appellants additions

anchor.surface_text: Have the Haryana factories then not received in fact during 1970-71 the reasonable return as envisaged by sub-s. 3C? The actual figures of the year for duration and recovery were not in dispute. They were 162 days and 8.69 respectively... The average price thus realised comes to Rs. 130.77. There is no doubt that taking the picture as a whole the Haryana factories got in any event a reasonable return

arguments.claim: High Court price addition of Rs.3.22 making Rs.127.85 realistic; govt doesn't challenge

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, no doubt, did not hold the price of Rs. 124.63 as realistic and in view of the changes which had taken place during the year added in all Rs. 3.22... Adding Rs. 3.28 to the Government price, the High Court worked out the fair price at Rs. 127.85 instead of Rs. 124.63. We need not examine the correctness or otherwise of this addition as the Solicitor General told us that he did not challenge the correctness of this addition.

arguments.claim: Increase in purchase tax absorbed in prior cushion; actuals better than estimated

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor General also conceded that purchase tax on cane in Haryana was increased during the year 1970-71 from 24 paise to 50 paise per quintal with effect from April 1, 1970 and that increase according to para 11 of the return, dated May 1971 was not taken into account as the Government was of the opinion that the price of 1969-70, which was adopted for 1970-71, contained sufficient cushion

arguments.court_reasoning: Consistent with facts; included in calculations

arguments.claim: Price Rs.126.93 on available data incl tax increase, wage impact

anchor.surface_text: The Government thereupon filed an additional affidavit of the Deputy Secretary to the Ministry of Agriculture dated September 14, 1971 according to which on the available data before it the price would come to Rs. 126.93. This figure took note of the increase in the purchase tax by Haryana Government from 24 to 50 paise per quintal of cane.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the factories would also suggest that the claim for Rs. 2.29 per quintal was number warranted. The total production by the Haryana factories during 19

arguments.court_reasoning: Basis disclosed; close to Tariff Comm figure

holdings.text: The true construction of S.3(3C) is that a fair price has to be determined in respect of the entire produce of sugar, having regard to minimum price of cane, manufacturing cost on zonal cost-schedules, taxes/duties, ensuring reasonable return on capital employed in the business of manufacturing sugar.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied both on the language of the sub-section, the background in which it was enacted and the mischief the legislature sought to remedy through its working that the true, construction is that a fair price has to be determined in respect of the entire produce, ensuring to the industry a reasonable return on the capital employed in the business of manufacturing sugar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language of sub-section, historical cost schedules by expert bodies for entire production since 1958, purpose of partial control to incentivize efficiency and higher cane prices via free market profits, harmonizing interests of cane growers, manufacturers, consumers.

holdings.text: Reasonable return under cl.(d) of S.3(3C) means return on capital employed in the business of manufacturing sugar as a whole and not merely on levy sugar production.

anchor.surface_text: In, this conclusion we derive a two-fold support, firstly, from the language used in cl. d itself, viz., a reasonable return on the capital employed in the business of manufacturing sugar, which must mean the business as a whole and not the business of manufacturing levy sugar only, and secondly, from the fact of the Commission having all along used the, same phraseology while recommending Rs. 10.50 per quintal as an addition by way of a reasonable return on the capital employed in the industry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: 'business of manufacturing sugar' means whole; consistent with Tariff Commission phraseology and zonal schedules for entire industry.

holdings.text: Fair price under S.3(3C) determined on basis of zonal averages from representative efficient cross-section of units, not unit-wise actual costs, to avoid rewarding inefficiency.

anchor.surface_text: A claim that such a price has to be determined unit-wise and a reasonable return has to be ensured to each unit or that such a price with such a return would be in respect of that part of its stock required to be sold under sub-sec. 2 f would appear to be inconsistent with the concept of partial control

holdings.reasoning_summary: Impracticable; perpetuates inefficiency; historical zonal schedules; partial control incentivizes efficiency via free market.

holdings.text: Price of Rs.124.63 per quintal fixed under Sugar Price Determination Order, 1971 for Haryana zone levy sugar accords with S.3(3C).

anchor.surface_text: the only question left for consideration is whether the price fixed under the impugned order, i.e., Rs. 124.63, is in consonance with s. 3 3C ? The ex-works price worked out in the Tariff Commission Re- port, 1969 for Haryana zone for the next three years, i.e., 1969-70 to 1971-72, based on the average recovery and average duration of the past five years  1963-64 to 1967- 68 , i.e., 8.70 and 125 days, was Rs. 128.69 per quintal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on Tariff Commission 1969 cost schedules minus deferred rehabilitation Rs.2, adjustments for tax/wages/depreciation/packing to Rs.126.93; actual realizations levy+free Rs.130.77 exceed costs Rs.130.13 incl petitioner additions.

holdings.text: Haryana sugar factories received reasonable return on capital employed during 1970-71 as envisaged by S.3(3C).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Actual duration 162 days, recovery 8.69%; costs per zonal schedule + additions Rs.130.13; realizations Rs.130.77 on levy+free sugar up to decontrol; higher post-decontrol.

holdings.text: Government cannot fix arbitrary price under S.3(3C) inconsistent with guidelines or reasonable return, as it would contravene Arts.19(1)(f),(g) and 31.

anchor.surface_text: But this does not mean that Government can fix any arbitrary price, or a price fixed on extraneous considerations or such that it does not secure a reasonable return on the capital employed in the industry. Such a fixation would at once evoke a challenge, both on the ground of its being inconsistent with the guidelines built in the sub-section and its being in contravention of Arts. 19 1  f  and  g , and 31.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical; constitutionality not challenged in appeals.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals fail and are dismissed. In view of the somewhat complicated questions as to the meaning and interpretation of sec. 3 3C  of the Act, we direct that the parties will bear their own costs throughout. Liberty to the parties to file applic

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed; no case made out for quashing the Sugar Price Determination Order, 1971; price fixed by Government held consistent with s. 3(3C) of the Essential Commodities Act
directions: parties will bear their own costs throughout
Liberty to the parties to file applications for directions in respect of the Bank Guarantees furnished by them in pursuance of stay orders passed by this Court

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied both on the language of the sub-section, the background in which it was enacted and the mischief the legislature sought to remedy through its working that the true, construction is that a fair price has to be determined in respect of the entire produce, ensuring to the industry a reasonable return on the capital employed in the business of manufacturing sugar.

In the result the appeals fail and are dismissed. In view of the somewhat complicated questions as to the meaning and interpretation of sec. 3 3C  of the Act, we direct that the parties will bear their own costs throughout. Liberty to the parties to file applic

anchor.surface_text: In, this conclusion we derive a two-fold support, firstly, from the language used in cl. d itself, viz., a reasonable return on the capital employed in the business of manufacturing sugar, which must mean the business as a whole and not the business of manufacturing levy sugar only, and secondly, from the fact of the Commission having all along used the, same phraseology while recommending Rs. 10.50 per quintal as an addition by way of a reasonable return on the capital employed in the industry.

In the result the appeals fail and are dismissed. In view of the somewhat complicated questions as to the meaning and interpretation of sec. 3 3C  of the Act, we direct that the parties will bear their own costs throughout. Liberty to the parties to file applic
